doc.title: Directive on the Management of Projects and Programmes

notetoreader.p: Appendices F, G and H set out the authorities that are required from Treasury Board with respect to managing a programme. The content of the appendices has been developed based on international best practices and in consultation with pathfinder programmes in the Government of Canada context. Given that programme management is new to the Government of Canada, these appendices are a first iteration and may be revised to incorporate lessons from the management of different types of programmes across the government.

clauses.clause: This directive takes effect on April 11, 2019 .

clause.p: This directive replaces the following Treasury Board policy instruments:

ul.li:
Policy on the Management of Projects
( December 10, 2009 )

Standard for Organizational Project Management Capacity
( December 09, 2010 )

Standard for Project Complexity and Risk
( December 09, 2010 )

clause.p: Departments will have six months to transition to the new directive. With the following exceptions, requirements will come into full effect on October 11, 2019 .
Effective immediately:

ul.li: Appendix C: Project Approval Limits

clause.p: Effective one year from the effective date in section 1.1:

ul.li: Requirement 4.1.6

clauses.clause: In-flight projects, with final authorities in place as of the effective date in section 1.1 and that are scheduled to close within one year from the effective date, will be exempt from transitioning to the directive.
This directive is issued pursuant to section 7 of the Financial Administration Act and section 31 of the Public Service Employment Act .

The objective of this directive is that government projects and programmes are effectively planned, implemented, monitored and controlled, and closed to enable the realization of the expected benefits and results for Canadians.

clause.p: The expected results of this directive are as follows:

clauses.clause: Governance and controls over projects and programmes are effective;
Decisions are made throughout the life of the project and programme with a view to maximizing efficiency and ensuring the realization of benefits;
Performance measurement data are used in support of regular monitoring of project and programme health and evidence-based decision-making; and
Capacity for project and programme management, commensurate with organizational need, is developed and maintained.

chapter.title: Requirements
chapter.p: Senior designated official(s) for the management of projects and programmes

clause.p: The senior designated official(s) for the management of projects and programmes is responsible for the following:

clauses.clause: Establishing, documenting, and maintaining a department-wide project and programme management framework, consisting of processes, systems and controls, anchored in professional best practices;
Consulting key departmental stakeholders including procurement, real property, information technology, finance, and human resources in the development of the project and programme framework;

clause.p: Embedding within the project and programme framework an approach to project gating, that establishes;

clauses.clause: The project gates that each project and programme must pass through;
The evidence required in support of gate decisions; and
The process for documenting the gate decisions;

Making available to all departments and agencies, in a manner and timeframe determined by the Comptroller General of Canada, the deputy head approved departmental project and programme management framework;

clause.p: Supporting management and expenditure decision-making, accountability, and transparency by establishing:

clauses.clause: Processes for the monitoring and control of the departmentâs projects and programmes; and
Standard performance measures and performance measurement tracking processes for the departmentâs projects and programmes;

clause.p: For all projects with a total cost of $25 million or greater, collecting and submitting to the Office of the Comptroller General, baseline project information on scope, schedule, costs, and risks, following receipt of:

ul.li: Project approval;
Expenditure authority;
Amended project approval;
Amended expenditure authority; and
Project close-out;

clauses.clause: Implementing processes that promote the coordinated management of related projects and programmes to reduce risk, contribute to shared outcomes, and realize efficiencies and benefits not available from managing the projects and programmes individually;
Identifying and addressing the departmentâs needs with respect to acquiring the necessary knowledge, experience, and skills in project and programme management;
Putting in place a process to collect and make available best practices and lessons-learned;
Completing the Organizational Project Management Capacity Assessment as provided for in Appendix A: Mandatory Procedures for Organizational Project Management Capacity Assessment ; and
Establishing processes and standards, consistent with direction provided by the Comptroller General of Canada, for the authoring, review and approval of Project Complexity and Risk Assessments.

clause.p: The project sponsor (programme sponsor) is responsible for the following:

clauses.clause: The planning, definition, implementation, transition, and close-out of the project or programme;
Providing visible active leadership and timely direction to mitigate project and programme risks, resolve issues, and act on opportunities;

Collaborating with key departmental stakeholders such as procurement, real property, information technology, finance, legal, and human resources in the planning and implementation of the project or programme;
Where applicable, seeking integrated approval of the project, programme, procurement and real property authorities;
Maintaining effective relationships with key external stakeholders including implicated departments and common service providers;
Ensuring where business change is required to achieve the business outcomes, that the project and programme scope of work includes all the activities and outputs necessary to bring about this change;
Ensuring programmes employ an appropriately flexible procurement strategy, to reduce risk and/or provide opportunity for earlier, incremental realization of benefits; and
Applying as appropriate, incremental, iterative, agile, and user-centric principles and methods to the planning, definition, and implementation of the project or programme;
Communicating roles, responsibilities, accountability, and authority for project and programme governance to all key stakeholders;
Enable effective decision-making by ensuring essential project and programme information and performance measures are tracked and shared with all key stakeholders;

clause.p: Exercising due care in the assignment of the project manager by ensuring the project manager has the required competencies and experience to manage:

clauses.clause: The work needed to realize the projectâs outputs; and
The relative complexity, risk, materiality, and significance of the project;
Documenting roles and responsibilities, and delegating authorities to the project manager through a project charter;
Documenting and communicating project and programme governance decisions to the project and programme team and all key stakeholders;
Assessing the project and programme governance to confirm its effectiveness and inclusiveness, and adjusting it as needed; and
Ensuring that the level of seniority at which governance is exercised and the frequency of governance meetings are commensurate with the complexity and risk of the project or programme;

header.p: Additional governance requirements for joint and enterprise projects and programmes

clauses.clause: Working with key stakeholders to establish a common governance framework and mechanisms; and

Ensuring the roles, responsibilities, accountabilities and authorities of all departments are documented in signed agreements and are reviewed and maintained throughout the life-cycle of the project or programme;

clause.p: Establishing a project gating plan at the outset of the project, consistent with the departmentâs framework, that;

clauses.clause: Documents the decisions that will be taken at each gate, the evidence and information required in support of the gate decisions, the criteria used to assess the evidence, and the gate governance; and
Reflects the specific risks of the project; input from key departmental and external stakeholders; the procurement strategy; and project dependencies and constraints;

Including at each gate: a revalidation of the business case; confirmation that the intended benefits are still relevant and attainable; and an overall determination of the ongoing viability of the project;
For gate decisions involving consideration of operational readiness or deployment decisions, seeking and documenting input from stakeholders that are affected by the decision;
Conducting assurance activities and independent reviews in accordance with the project gating plan; and
For each gate, making a determination as to whether the project has met the requirements of the gate; and

header.p: Additional gating requirements for joint and enterprise projects

clauses.clause: Ensuring that gate decisions consider the interests and input of all impacted stakeholders;
Ensuring the completion of the project complexity and risk assessment in accordance with Appendix B: Mandatory Procedures for Project Complexity and Risk Assessment;

Seeking project approval and expenditure authority as per the requirements outlined in Appendix C: Project Approval Limits and Appendix D: Programme Approval, Project Approval and Expenditure Authority; and programme approval and expenditure authority as per the requirements outlined in Appendix F: Programme Approval and Expenditure Authority, Appendix G: Programme Brief for Definition, and Appendix H: Programme Brief for Implementation (Tranche)
Support decision-making by integrating procurement planning in project approvals by ensuring that requests for project approval include market analysis and procurement strategies;

p.strong: Benefits management and transition to operations

clauses.clause: Ensuring that the projectâs and programmeâs expected outcomes and benefits are clearly defined and measurable as an input into the business case;
Ensuring that a benefits realization plan is in place at the time of project programme approval and is monitored and updated throughout the project programme life-cycle;
Ensuring the business owner(s) responsible for the realization of benefits is identified in the benefits realization plan;

clause.p: To support transition of the project or programme to operations, ensuring that:

clauses.clause: A transition plan is developed prior to the commencement of the implementation phase; and
The transition plan is updated throughout the project or programme life-cycle;

header.p: Additional requirements for joint and enterprise projects and programmes

clauses.clause: Working with participating departments to ensure that requirements 4.2.27 through 4.2.30 reflect a joint or enterprise perspective;
Reviewing, at the commencement of a project or programme, lessons learned from similar project or programme;
At the end of each project phase, documenting lessons learned and sharing with all key stakeholders and the Senior Designated Official responsible for the management of projects and programmes; and

Completing a project or programme close-out report and sharing with the departmental committee that approved the project or programme as well as the Senior Designated Official responsible for the management of projects and programmes;

clause.p: The Secretary of the Treasury Board is responsible for the following:

clauses.clause: Establishing and documenting processes for the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat (TBS) review of departmentsâ Organizational Project Management Capacity Assessments and Project Complexity and Risk Assessments;

clause.p: The Comptroller General of Canada is responsible for:

clauses.clause: Providing government-wide functional leadership to the project management community, including the development and sustainability of the project management community through talent management and community development strategies;

clause.p: The Chief Information Officer of Canada is responsible for:
Establishing a digital investment oversight program and, as part of that program:

clauses.clause: Identifying those digital projects or programmes that are subject to oversight by the Chief Information Officer of Canada; and

clause.p: Conducting oversight activities with respect to identified digital projects or programmes, including:

clauses.clause: Requiring the responsible deputy head to commission, at the relevant departmentâs cost, one or more independent reviews of projects or programmes to ascertain whether specific actions are required to address issues or mitigate risks;

Commissioning one or more independent reviews of projects or programmes, at the relevant departmentâs cost, to ascertain whether specific actions are required to address issues or mitigate risks; and

Requiring the responsible deputy head to undertake specific course corrections as deemed necessary by the Chief Information Officer of Canada based on evidence gathered in the course of overseeing identified projects or programmes;
Recommending cancellation of digital projects or programmes to the Treasury Board when evidence demonstrates that the project or programme is not viable; and
Assigning a project sponsor for a digital project that involves multiple departments (joint or enterprise projects) and for which a single responsible project sponsor has not been named.
Not applicable.
This directive and related appendices apply to the organizations listed in section 6.1 of the Policy on the Planning and Management of Investments .
This directive and related appendices apply to all Government of Canada projects and programmes as defined in the Policy on the Planning and Management of Investments .

Requirements within this directive and related appendices are to be applied in a scalable fashion commensurate with the needs of the department and the risk and complexity of the project or programme.
Requirements 4.1.1 through 4.1.4 apply to those departments with an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class of 1 and higher.
Requirement 4.1.10 and Appendix A apply to those departments seeking a project approval authority limit greater than the base limit of $2.5 million.

This directive does not apply to projects funded by the federal government through transfer payments. The Treasury Board
Policy on Transfer Payments
and its supporting directives set out requirements for managing and approving projects funded through transfer payments.

appendix.title: Appendix A: Mandatory Procedures for Organizational Project Management Capacity Assessments

clauses.clause: These procedures take effect on April 11, 2019 .

clause.p: These procedures replace the following Treasury Board policy instruments:

ul.li:
Standard for Organizational Project Management Capacity Assessments
( December 9, 2010 )

clauses.clause: These procedures provide details on the requirement set out in section 4.1.10 of the Directive on the Management of Projects and Programmes .

clause.p: Mandatory procedures are as follows:

clauses.clause: All departments seeking an increase to the base project approval authority limit of $2.5 million must do so using the Organizational Project Management Capacity Assessment (OPMCA).
The assessment measures the capacity of a department to successfully deliver a defined volume of work over a fixed period of time.

clause.p: The generally accepted method to establish this volume of work is to prepare a list of all planned and active projects of $2.5 million and greater, covering the period of time for which the requested authority will be in effect.

clauses.clause: If this is not practicable, the department must meet with TBS in advance of starting the OPMCA and confirm how the volume of work will be established and communicated.

header.strong: Evidence in support of the OPMCA

clauses.clause: TBS must be consulted at the start of the process to confirm the evidence that will be used to support the OPMCA;

clause.p: Sources of evidence must include:

clauses.clause: A representative sample of recent projects;
Findings from the past three years of internal or external audits, evaluations, reports, or other findings addressing the departments project management capacity; and
Treasury Board conditions from the past three years pertaining to project management capacity.
Submit the draft OPMCA, with its evidence, to TBS for review.
Revise, if necessary, the OPMCA based on TBSâs feedback.
Submit the deputy headÃ¢ÂÂapproved final OPMCA to TBS through the approved centralized application.
Prepare the Treasury Board submission to seek approval of the Organizational Project Management Capacity Assessment Class.

header.strong: Changes in Organizational Project Management Capacity Assessments

clauses.clause: Inform TBS in a timely manner of any significant changes to the organizational project management capacity that may affect the Treasury Board approved capacity class.
If requested by TBS, revise the OPMCA.

li.em: Guide to Using the Organizational Project Management Assessment Tool

ul.li: Organizational Project Management Assessment Tool

appendix.title: Appendix B: Mandatory Procedures for Project Complexity and Risk Assessments

clauses.clause: These procedures take effect on April 11, 2019 .

clause.p: These procedures replace the following Treasury Board policy instruments:

ul.li: Standard for Project Complexity and Risk Assessments (2010)

clauses.clause: These procedures provide details on the requirements set out in subsection 4.2.24 of the Directive on the Management of Projects and Programmes .

clause.p: Mandatory procedures are as follows:

clauses.clause: The assessment is to be completed for all projects as per the Project Complexity and Risk Assessment (PCRA) thresholds established in Appendix C: Project Approval Limits.
The assessment is to be completed using the Project Complexity and Risk Assessment.
The assessment must take into account the full scope and life-cycle of the project.

header.strong: Submitting the Project Complexity and Risk Assessment

clause.p: Prior to the commencement of the definition phase, submit the assessment, with reference to the supporting evidence, to TBS for review and confirmation of the assessed level of complexity and risk.

clauses.clause: For departments with an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Assessment class, the Project Complexity and Risk Assessment is to be submitted through the centralized application.

clause.p: TBS will review the assessed level of complexity and risk within 15 working days after the submission of the PCRA.

clauses.clause: As part of its review, TBS may request the department provide supporting documentation.

In the event that TBS does not raise questions or request additional information within 15 working days after the submission of the PCRA, the department may assume TBS is in agreement with the assessed level of complexity and risk.

header.strong: Changes in project complexity and risk assessments

clauses.clause: If during the life-cycle of the project there are significant changes that would increase the assessed level of complexity or risk, the complexity and risk is to be reassessed.
Following consultations, TBS may request that a revised assessment, with reference to the supporting evidence, is to be submitted for review.

appendix.title: Appendix C: Project Approval Limits
appendix.p: In exercising oversight, the Treasury Board limits the expenditure authority exercised by ministers in the approval of projects.
All departments and agencies subject to this directive have a base project approval authority limit of $2.5 million (inclusive of the Goods and Services Tax and the Harmonized Sales Tax).

The basis for determining the capacity to manage projects, and seeking an increase to this base amount, is provided in the Mandatory Procedures for Organizational Project Management Capacity . Once approved by Treasury Board, the Organizational Project Management Capacity Class establishes a ministerâs project approval authority limit.

Departments without an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class or an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class of 0 are to seek the approval of Treasury Board for all projects over $2.5 million (inclusive of the Goods and Services Tax and the Harmonized Sales Tax).

For departments with an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class of 1 or higher, the basis for the determination of the appropriate approval authority is the relationship between the approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class of the department and the assessed Project Complexity and Risk Level of the project. Treasury Board may require any project to be brought forward for their consideration and approval.
The threshold for completing a PCRA is as follows:

ul.li: $2.5 million for departments without an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class or with an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class of 0,
$5 million for departments with an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class of 1,
$10 million for departments with an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class of 2,
$25 million for departments with an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class of 3, and
$50 million for departments with an approved Organizational Project Management Capacity Class of 4.

appendix.p: The results of the PCRA will confirm the approval authority and inform the planning, resourcing, governance and management of the project.

appendix.title: Appendix D: Project Approval and Expenditure Authority

clause.p: Projects within a ministerâs project approval authority limit

All projects within a ministerâs project approval authority limit must be supported by a business case and require documented project approval. This approval is to be sought in accordance with the processes prescribed within the departmental project and programme management framework.
Projects exceeding a ministerâs project approval authority limit

Projects exceeding a ministerâs project approval authority limit must be approved by Treasury Board and require two distinct and explicit approvals: project approval and project expenditure authority.

ul.li: In providing project approval, Treasury Board agrees that a requirement has been identified and that there is adequate justification for meeting that requirement through the proposed project. Once granted, project approval will establish a distinct project baseline. A request for project approval must be supported by an indicative cost estimate.

Project expenditure authority is the authority to expend funds against project-related activities for which the authority was sought. Project expenditure authority granted by Treasury Board indicates that sufficient information is available, at an appropriate level of detail, to proceed with a set of planned activities within a project phase or phases. A request for project expenditure authority must be supported by a substantive cost estimate.

clause.p: Departments must seek project approval and project expenditure authority from Treasury Board in accordance with the following instructions.
Project definition
Departments must seek project expenditure authority in order to commence project definition activities. Project approval from the Treasury Board is not required at this stage of the project.

ul.li: Prior to receiving project expenditure authority approval from Treasury Board for project definition activities, the responsible ministersâ authority is limited to those activities necessary to seek this approval such as options analysis, feasibility studies, socio-economic studies, technical investigations, market analysis, topographic surveys, and pricing and availability studies. These activities are commonly referred to as pre-definition activities.

clause.p: Project implementation
Departments must seek both project approval and project expenditure authority in order to commence project implementation activities.
Amendments
Amended project approval and/or project expenditure authority must be sought from Treasury Board when:

ul.li: the total estimated cost changes such that it exceeds the expenditure authority approved by Treasury Board, or
there is a significant change to the anticipated outcomes and benefits identified at time of approval, or
there has been a significant change to the project baseline established at time of approval.

clause.p: When it is clear that one or more of the above conditions will be realized, departments must initiate in a timely fashion, the process of seeking amended approval and/or authorities.
Project submission documentation requirements
Requests for project approval, project expenditure authority, or amendments to the same must be supported by the following documentation:

ul.li: the Project Brief (including the project cost and an estimate of associated life-cycle costs) developed in accordance with Appendix E

li.p: The following documents (or their equivalent(s)) may be requested by TBS at the same time as the draft submission:

ul.li: Business Case
Project Management Plan
Project Gating Plan
Procurement Plan
Appointment Letter (where applicable)
Project Charter
Other plans or documents may also be requested by TBS as and when required.

section.p: In cases where projects also include real property transactions and/or contracting activities which also require Treasury Board approval, departments are encouraged to coordinate all required approvals (project, real property and procurement) to provide a consolidated view to Treasury Board ministers and in doing so, minimize the number of submissions.

clauses.clause: A project brief must provide Treasury Board, the sponsoring minister, senior departmental officials, and TBS with a clear and concise understanding of the proposed initiative.

clause.p: A project brief must include a description of:

clauses.clause: The expected outcomes of the project; the relationship of the outcomes to the sponsoring departmentâs mandate and programs and to government-wide results; and the significance of the project within the context of the departmentâs investment plan;
The level of service or capability to be developed or improved; a general description of the output(s); and the outcome(s) to be achieved;
A summary of the benefits realization plan including indication of the timing of the expected benefits;
The results of the business case, including a description of each option, the assessment criteria, and a summary of the results of the comparative assessment;
For the recommended option, the scope, schedule, cost and other critical objectives that will form the project baseline;
The estimated life-cycle costs associated with the project;

The procurement strategy, including any relevant market information, interdepartmental procurement review process and the proposed strategy for soliciting and awarding relevant contracts, when required;
The risk management plan including identification of key risks, their probability and potential impact, and the plan to proactively monitor and control them;

Other features of the project that could affect its progress, such as privacy and environmental issues, land claims, regulatory or legislative changes and agreements with other governments, including international or domestic participants;
The segmenting of the project into gates and the controls for managing transitions through the gates;
The proposed timing of engagements with Treasury Board or TBS;
The performance and outcome measures, including an assessment strategy and provision for independent third-party evaluations when required;

clause.p: The governance and management approach to the overall project including:

ul.li: Accountability for project outcomes;
Documented roles and responsibilities of participating departments and of the different units within the lead department;
The structure and committees focused on governing the project and achieving the project and programme outcomes;

clauses.clause: The communications strategy including identification, nature, and extent of consultations with key stakeholders; and
The results of the project complexity and risk assessment.

appendix.title: Appendix F: Programme Approval and Expenditure Authority

clauses.clause: The process for programme approval is reserved for large business-transformation initiatives.

Before seeking programme approval, departments must confirm with the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat (TBS) that the investment under consideration constitutes a large business-transformation initiative that should be managed under the process for programme approval and that the organization is ready to undertake the initiative using a programme-management approach.

The investment under consideration will be screened in collaboration with TBS, and the results will inform the determination by TBS of whether an initiative will be managed under the process for programme approval.
Departments must also provide evidence that their deputy head-approved departmental programme-management framework is in place with the required governance.

clause.p: All programmes require two distinct and explicit approvals from Treasury BoardÂ Ã¢ÂÂÂ programme approval and expenditure authorityÂ Ã¢ÂÂÂ which are described below:

clauses.clause: In providing programme approval, the Treasury Board agrees that a large business-transformation initiative has been identified with sufficient complexity and interdependencies to warrant setting up a programme;
Programme approval provides authorization to seek expenditure authority, but it does not, in and of itself, convey authority to expend funds on the programme;
Expenditure authority provides the authority to expend funds against the activities for which the authority was sought; and

Expenditure authority granted by Treasury Board indicates that sufficient information is available, at an appropriate level of detail, to justify the expenditure of funds on a particular phase or tranche of the programme.

Before receiving programme approval from Treasury Board, the sponsoring ministerâs authority is limited to the activities necessary to seek the initial programme approval and expenditure authority in support of the definition phase.

Before programme approval, the use of proofs of concept, prototypes and pilots are to be limited to the activities necessary to seek the initial programme approval and expenditure authority in support of the definition phase.
Departments will need to seek the agreement of TBS in order to proceed with a pilot before programme approval.

header.strong: Submission for programme approval and expenditure authority for the definition phase

clause.p: Following the conclusion of the initial planning and identification phase, the sponsoring minister for a programme will seek:

clauses.clause: Programme approval for the programme, as well as expenditure authority for the definition phase; and
As appropriate, a separate expenditure authority to advance implementation activities in keeping with subsectionÂ F.7.1.
The request for programme approval is to be supported by a rough order of magnitude (ROM) cost estimate.
The request for expenditure authority in support of the definition phase is to be supported by a substantive cost estimate.

clause.p: This submission for programme approval and expenditure authority for the definition phase must be supported by the following documentation:
Appended to the submission:

ul.li: Programme brief for definition

clause.p: Provided to TBS in support of the submission:

ul.li: Appointment letter for the programme sponsor

clauses.clause: Other plans or documents may be requested by TBS, as and when required, to support the submission process.
Once granted, programme approval will establish an agreed upon programme baseline.
Following completion of the definition phase, the projects and activities that comprise the programme will be grouped into tranches.

clause.p: Each tranche will be the subject of a separate submission with the sponsoring minister, and each submission will:

clauses.clause: Update the programme baseline;
Seek expenditure authority for the tranche;

As appropriate, seek authority to approve projects within the tranche that exceed the limits set out in Appendix C: Project Approval Limits of the Directive on the Management of Projects and Programmes ; and
As appropriate, seek associated real property and contracting authorities in keeping with subsectionÂ F.8.1.
The updated programme baseline is to be supported by a ROM cost estimate.
The request for expenditure authority in support of a tranche is to be supported by an indicative cost estimate.

clause.p: Submissions requesting expenditure authority in support of a tranche must be supported by the following documentation:
Appended to the submission:

ul.li: Programme brief for implementation (tranche)

clause.p: Provided to TBS in support of the submission:

ul.li: Programme business case
Programme target operating model (or equivalent)
Programme plan (or equivalent)
Projects dossier (or equivalent)

clauses.clause: Other plans or documents may be requested by TBS, as and when required.
Once granted, expenditure authority will establish an agreed upon baseline for the programme phase or tranche.

clause.p: Amended authority in terms of programme approval must be sought from Treasury Board when:

clauses.clause: The total estimated cost of the programme changes such that it exceeds the estimate approved by the Treasury Board as part of the most recent programme approval; or
There will be significant change to the programme baseline (capabilities, outcomes and benefits) established through the most recent programme approval.

clause.p: Amended authority in terms of expenditure must be sought from Treasury Board when:

clauses.clause: The total estimated cost changes such that it exceeds the expenditure limit (expenditure authority) approved by the Treasury Board; or
There is significant change to the deliverables in terms of capabilities, outcomes and benefits established as part of the expenditure authority.

When it is clear that amended authorities are required, departments must initiate the process of seeking amended authorities in a timely fashion before the existing authority is exceeded or changes to the baseline are introduced.

The expenditure authority for a tranche sets an expenditure ceiling for the realization of the capabilities and outcomes linked to the tranche. The combined costs of the projects and activities within the tranche cannot exceed this ceiling.

The expenditure authority for a tranche may only be allocated to the projects and programme activities required to deliver the capabilities identified in the submission, and to undertake the planning of the next tranche.
The projects within a tranche are not approved by Treasury Board as part of the submission.

clause.p: Subject to the appropriate governance and approvals, changes can be made to the projects that make up a tranche as long as:

clauses.clause: The underlying tranche capability is delivered; and
The total cost of the tranche does not exceed the expenditure authority approved by the Treasury Board.

header.strong: Projects within a tranche where the Project Complexity and Risk Assessment (PCRA) level is within the Organizational Project Management Capacity (OPMC) class

clauses.clause: Projects where the PCRA level is within the approved departmental OPMC class are to be approved and managed in keeping with the requirements set out in the Policy on the Planning and Management of Investments and the Directive on the Management of Projects and Programmes .

header.strong: Projects within a tranche where the PCRA level exceeds the OPMC class

clause.p: If a tranche includes or may include projects where the PCRA will exceed the approved departmental OPMC class, the sponsoring minister may choose to seek authority to approve these projects:

clauses.clause: This request must be supported by information that demonstrates that the programme has taken the necessary steps to put in place the capacity to manage projects that exceed the approved departmental OPMC class;
This authority is only for the projects related to the tranche for which it is sought and is not transferable. The sponsoring minister must seek this authority for each tranche; and

Projects approved under this authority are to be approved and managed in keeping with the requirements set out in the Policy on the Planning and Management of Investments and the Directive on the Management of Projects and Programmes .

If the sponsoring minister does not seek this authority or Treasury Board does not grant it, the sponsoring minister must seek a distinct Treasury Board project approval and expenditure authority for each project that exceeds the approved departmental OPMC class in keeping with the requirements set out in the Policy on the Planning and Management of Investments and the Directive on the Management of Projects and Programmes .

header.strong: Seeking authority to advance implementation activities during the definition phase

clause.p: When requesting expenditure authority for the definition phase, the sponsoring minister may seek authority to accelerate implementation work that is considered foundational to the programme:

clauses.clause: The request must be supported by a rationale and justification that demonstrates that the benefits of proceeding with the work exceed the risks of doing so; and
The request must be supported by an indicative cost estimate.

In cases where programmes involve real property transactions or procurement activities that also require Treasury Board approval, departments are encouraged, where appropriate, to coordinate all required approvals (programme, real property and procurement) to provide a consolidated view to Treasury Board ministers.

appendix.title: AppendixÂ G: Programme Brief for Definition

clauses.clause: A programme brief must provide the Treasury Board, the sponsoring minister, senior departmental officials, and the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat (TBS) with a clear and measurable description of the proposed initiative.

clause.p: For the programme as a whole, the programme brief must make clear:

clauses.clause: The strategic objectives of the programme, the vision statement, the relationship to the sponsoring departmentâs mandate and programs and to government-wide results, and the significance of the programme within the context of the departmentâs investment plan;

The expected capabilities resulting from the programme, the level of service or capability to be developed or improved as a result of the programme, the impact on the target organization or organizations of the proposed development or improvement of capabilities, and the current state of these services and capabilities;
The anticipated benefits to stakeholders throughout the programme life-cycle that demonstrate an incremental approach and a continual iteration of benefits management;
The initial understanding of the benefits, including an indication of the timing of the expected benefits and how they will be measured;
The organization (structure and committees) and governance in place to manage and oversee the programme;
The initial understanding of the estimated cost, schedule, and resources required to set up, run and manage the programme from definition through to close-out;

clause.p: The initial understanding of the projects and activities that will be included in the programme;

clauses.clause: A list of any projects and activities that have started and that will be absorbed into the programme or terminated as a result of the programme;
The initial understanding of risks and issues, including key assumptions and constraints, and the way they will be managed;
The degree to which stakeholders have been engaged and the level of support demonstrated;

The aspects of the programme environment that could affect its progress, such as privacy and environmental issues, land claims, regulatory or legislative changes, and agreements with other governments, including international or domestic participants;
The initial understanding of the performance and benefit measures, including an approach to assessment and initial assurance arrangements;
The preliminary procurement strategy and plan and the supporting rationale; and
The proposed timing of engagements with the Treasury Board or TBS.

clause.p: For the programme definition phase, the programme brief must make clear:
The outputs of the programme definition phase;

clauses.clause: If the definition phase includes a proof of concept or prototype, the details of these undertakings, including the objective, how success will be measured and any procurements required;
The identified cost and resources required to complete the definition phase;
The schedule of activities to achieve the outputs of the programme definition phase;
The plan to put in place the capabilities and resources required to complete the definition phase;
The stakeholder analysis and engagement required for programme definition, including the identification, nature and extent of consultations with key stakeholders;
The governance and assurance arrangements that will be applied to the definition phase; and
Key procurement decisions that will be actioned during the definition phase.

clause.p: If a tranche submission for a programme includes a request for the delegated authority to approve projects within the tranche that exceed the approved Organizational Project Management Capacity class for the department, the programme brief must make clear:

clauses.clause: The gap or gaps in the capacity for organizational project management in relation to the complexity and risk of the project or projects;
Actions that have been or will be taken within the programme to address the gap or gaps;
The details of the assurance arrangements that have been or will be put in place to confirm the efficacy of the actions taken to address the gap or gaps; and
The individual who will be sub-delegated by the minister to approve the projects (expressed in terms of their position within the programme governance).
